Fig. 2 Schematic acidic OER mechanisms. (a) AEM. (b) LOM. (c) OPM. Fig. 3 (a) Schematic illustration of the synthetic procedure for the core-shell Co3O4@CoRuO x nanocones on CC. (b) Schematic illustration of OER process in alkaline/acidic media. (c) Calculated DOS of CoRuO x , CoRuO x without lattice compression, and RuO2 (left) and calculated O p-orbitals adsorbed on CoRuO x and RuO2 (right), and the schematic diagram of corresponding antibonding and bonding formation (middle). Graphical abstract The latest progress of Ru-based catalysts for acidic media is reviewed and specifically, feasible strategies for optimizing OER performance based on these mechanisms are provided. Water electrolysis using proton-exchange membranes is one of the most promising technologies for carbon-neutral and sustainable energy production. Generally, the overall efficiency of water splitting is limited by the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Nevertheless, a trade-off between activity and stability exists for most electrocatalytic materials in strong acids and oxidizing media, and the development of efficient and stable catalytic materials has been an important focus of research. In this view, gaining in-depth insights into the OER system, particularly the interactions between reaction intermediates and active sites, is significantly important. To this end, this review introduces the fundamentals of the OER over Ru-based materials, including the conventional adsorbate evolution mechanism, lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism, and oxide path mechanism. Moreover, the up-to-date progress of representative modifications for improving OER performance is further discussed with reference to specific mechanisms, such as tuning of geometric, electronic structures, incorporation of proton acceptors, and optimization of metal-oxygen covalency. Finally, some valuable insights into the challenges and opportunities for OER electrocatalysts are provided with the aim to promote the development of next-generation catalysts with high activity and excellent stability. Keywords Oxygen evolution reaction Ru-based electrocatalysts Acidic solutions Mechanism Proton-exchange membranes 1 Introduction The increasing consumption of fossil fuels has resulted in considerable environmental degradation, air pollution, and global warming [1–3]. These problems have led to rising demands for green and sustainable energy sources such as wind, solar, and hydroelectric power [4,5]. Furthermore, because these renewable energy sources are available indefinitely, there is a pressing need to develop effective energy storage and conversion systems [6–8]. The electrolysis of water, as a green method for efficiently converting renewable energy to stable hydrogen energy for storage, is essential for the development of a society fueled by sustainable hydrogen energy [9–14]. Compared with alkaline water electrolysis, acidic water electrolysis offers remarkable advantages such as compact design, quick response, low ohmic losses, and high voltage efficiency [15–17], because the ion mobility and diffusion coefficient of OH− in anion exchange membrane are much lower than those of H+ in proton exchange membrane [18]. In addition, the mixture of hydrogen and oxygen can be effectively controlled within a safe range through proton-exchange membranes (PEMs), thus ensuring the safe operation of the electrolysis water unit. In addition, PEM's proton transport has a fast response to voltage, higher voltage efficiency and current density than anion-exchange membrane water electrolysis, higher safety, and simpler installation, so it is more promising in hydrogen production [19–21]. However, the kinetically slow OER, which involves the formation of OO bonds and four-electron transfer processes [22–25], requires higher voltages to drive the actual water electrolysis and results in much lower energy utilization efficiency. To date, significant efforts have been devoted to the design and development of OER electrocatalysts with fast kinetics and high stability; however, most of them still do not exhibit satisfactory catalytic activity and stability, especially under harsh acidic conditions [26–28]. Currently, as a benchmark for the acidic OER, iridium dioxide (IrO2) is considered the most promising PEM electrocatalyst that can meet the stability requirements for industrial-scale PEMs under acidic conditions [29,30]. However, the extreme scarcity and high cost of Ir resources greatly limit the large-scale application the IrO2 electrocatalyst [31]. Compared to Ir, Ru has obvious advantages in terms of cost (US$ 162.6 gIr − 1 vs. US$ 16.4 gRu −1) [32–35] and abundant reserves. In addition, Ru-based electrocatalysts have a wide modulation range of redox states, unique reaction pathways, and moderate binding ability of the oxidation intermediate; thus, its OER mass activity is higher than that of Ir-based catalysts [36–39]. Moreover, a combination of theoretical Pourbaix plot analysis and experimental results have suggested the potential of Ru-based OER electrocatalysts as an alternative to Ir-based systems [40–43]. However, the application of Ru-based electrocatalysts is limited because of many factors [27,44–46]. For example, during the acidic OER, oxygen vacancies or sub-stable amorphous RuO x are formed in the Ru-based electrocatalysts at the oxidation potential [47,48], which induces the leaching of Ru sites from the surface or bulk phase. This commonly leads to surface roughening and reconstruction of the active site, making it difficult to maintain the catalyst stability over a long time. As stated above, a deeper understanding of the intrinsic mechanism of the dynamic evolution of intermediates and charge transfer during the OER is essential, which can also provide valuable guidelines to design and develop high-performance OER electrocatalysts. Although several studies related to the design of high-performance acidic OER electrocatalysts have been published over the past few decades [41,48–54], a timely, comprehensive, and in-depth review of the mechanism is still highly desirable. First, several currently established OER mechanisms, including the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) [18,55], lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism (LOM) [23,56], and oxide path mechanism (OPM) [57], are summarized, and a feasible method for designing OER electrocatalysts is presented, as shown in Fig. 1 . Next, novel experimental evidence based on in situ spectroscopic studies as well as theoretical investigations is presented in detail to explain the OER mechanisms and our structure-activity understanding of Ru-based electrocatalysts. More importantly, some promising strategies used to obtain highly active sites and stability are analyzed, including tuning of geometric and electronic structures, introduction of proton acceptors, and optimization of metal-oxygen covalency. Then, the theoretical and commonly experimental methodologies for consolidating the arguments in the OER process will also be underlined. Finally, this review summarizes some unresolved issues and challenges in the experimental and theoretical investigations on the construction of active sites and mechanistic analyses with the aim to provide valuable prospects for future research on PEM-based electrocatalysts for the acidic OER. 2 OER mechanisms Based on OER studies, we discuss the three main mechanisms (i.e., the AEM, LOM and OPM) in detail. In the AEM (Fig. 2 a), oxygen evolution is a four-electron proton transfer process involving multiple intermediates (OH*, O* and OOH*) [58–60]. There exists an inherent linear scaling relationship between the adsorption energies of OOH* and OH* intermediates, due to the fact that the key steps of OH bond cleavage and OOH* formation are competing, rendering a minimum theoretical overpotential of 0.37 V [61]. In recent years, researchers have found that in the OER involving certain noble and transition metal (M) sites, MO bonds on the catalyst surface influence and participate in the oxygen evolution process, i.e., the OER occurs via the LOM (Fig. 2b). The activated lattice oxygen on the surface of the catalyst easily acts as an active site via nucleophile attack by OH*. In addition, with the release of gaseous O2 products, oxygen vacancies are formed and reoccupied by OH/H2O [62,63]. Furthermore, surface reconfiguration allows the activated lattice oxygen to bond directly to the O* intermediate, forming a high-valence metal cation. As such, catalysts that allow the OER to occur via the LOM can easily break the activity limits of those via the AEM and exhibit higher oxygen evolution activity. However, with the involvement of lattice oxygen, some of the oxygen vacancies appear on the surface of the catalyst, resulting in unsaturated metal sites to tend to dissolve in the electrolyte, which reduces the stability of the catalyst [64]. Compared with the AEM and LOM, the OPM is more suitable for developing high-performance OER electrocatalysts because it does not involve the formation of oxygen vacancy defects and permits direct O*O* radical coupling without the generation of OOH* [28,57]. Ideally, OPM-based multiphase electrocatalysts can overcome scaling relationships, while maintaining stability. However, the OPM places more stringent requirements on the geometrical arrangement of active metal sites than the AEM and LOM (Fig. 2c). Symmetrical bimetallic sites with appropriate atomic spacing (not too long or too short) are expected to facilitate the binding of O*O* radicals at relatively low potentials. 2.1 Adsorbate evolution mechanism The AEM involves the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates on the electrocatalyst with the metal site as the redox center, in which each step between the metal site and adsorbed oxygen intermediates involves a concerted electron-proton transfer process [65–67]. Specifically, the MOH* configuration is formed through the adsorption of H2O on the active site. Subsequently, MOH* undergoes deprotonation to MO* and further reacts with another H2O molecule to form MOOH* intermediates. Finally, O2 can be released by the deprotonation of MOOH* and reformation of the active site. The three oxygen-containing intermediates involved in the above electron transfer step are adsorbed on the surface via oxygen atoms, in which case the binding energies of OOH* and OH* are linearly related. However, this correlated binding energy relationship is ubiquitous on the surface of metals and metal oxides, independent of the binding strength of the surface and the binding site. Given the constant difference between the OOH* and OH* levels, the variation in the overpotential, η OER from one oxide surface to the next is determined by the O* adsorption energy. The theoretical overpotential can be expressed as: η OER = {max [(ΔG 0 O* − ΔG 0 OH*), 3.2 eV − (ΔG 0 O* − ΔG 0 OH*)]/e} − 1.23 V. The difference (ΔG 0 O* − ΔG 0 OH*) is therefore a unique descriptor for the OER activity [68,69]. The rate-determining step (RDS) can be benchmarked against the difference in the binding energy between ΔG O* and ΔG OH*—a result that has been supported by abundant experimental data [54,70]. According to the Sabatier principle, the ideal catalyst requires the adsorption strength of the key intermediate to be neither too strong nor too weak. The scaling relationship provides guidance for the rational design of efficient catalysts. To optimize the value of ΔG O* − ΔG OH*, it is possible to adjust the reaction path to increase the electrocatalytic activity via adjusting the electronic structure. 2.1.1 Electronic structure tuning To inhibit the dissolution of RuO2, the electronic structure, widely believed to be the key factor affecting Ru atom solvation, must be adjusted to eliminate the volatile low-coordination sites on the RuO2 surface by modulating the occupation of the 3d orbitals or oxygen vacancy [71–73]. To understand the driving force for the dissolution of Ru-based composites during the acidic OER, Jaramillo et al. [74]. designed and synthesized a series of Ru-based crystalline pyrochlores (A2Ru2O7, A = Y, Bi, Gd, and Nd). Through Pourbaix theoretical analysis, they found that the four pyrochlores were thermodynamically unstable within the potential range of the OER, and their dissolution behavior was associated with the A-site elements, indicating that the active sites can be stabilized effectively by regulating the composition of the Ru-based oxides. Meanwhile, the bulk structure determines the dissolution dynamics of catalysts. Ren et al. [75]. combined in situ metal-organic framework (MOF) derivatization with ion-exchange strategies to construct armor-like cobalt-doped RuO x shell layers (Co3O4@CoRuO x ) on the surface of Co3O4 nanocones with a low Ru content (<3.7 wt%) (Fig. 3 a). In 0.5 M H2SO4 solution, Co3O4@CoRuO x exhibited high catalytic activity, only requiring an overpotential of 161 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm− 2 during the OER. The catalyst also exhibited an ultrahigh mass activity (2069.0 A gRu − 1 at η = 270 mV). Experimental and DFT analysis indicated that the OER over the Co3O4@CoRuO x catalyst mainly followed the AEM (Fig. 3b), because the AEM does not involve lattice oxygen, and Ru atoms are hardly over-oxidized to form high-valent and soluble Ru x>4 [76,77]. It is shown that cobalt doping is accompanied by oxygen vacancies and lattice contraction in the RuO x lattice, causing the charge redistribution of neighboring Ru sites, gradually pushing the d-band center closer to the Fermi level. The optimized d-band center balances the adsorption energy of oxygenated intermediates and reduces the thermodynamic barrier of the rate determination step. At the same time, due to the p-band of lattice oxygen, the peroxidation and dissolution of Ru were inhibited, and the stability of the catalyst was enhanced (Fig. 3c), and the OER activity did not deteriorate significantly after 40 h under acidic conditions, suggesting excellent electrochemical stability. Recently, Huang et al. [78]. reported single-site Pt-doped RuO2 hollow nanospheres (SS Pt-RuO2 HNSs), in which C was doped in the interstices, and the Ru atoms were partially substituted by single Pt atoms. The SS Pt-RuO2 HNSs achieved current densities of 10, 50, and 100 mA cm−2 at small overpotentials of 228, 262 and 282 mV, respectively, during the OER. In addition, SS Pt-RuO2 HNSs can work continuously and stably for 100 h at a current density of 100 mA cm−2 in PEM electrolyzer, showing good stability. Through detailed characterization, it was found that the electronic structure of RuO2 was strongly modified by interstitial C and SS Pt, where the Ru–O and Pt–O bonds in the SS Pt-RuO2 HNSs were stretched (Fig. 3d). Theoretical calculations indicated that this strong synergy can significantly enhance the OER activity and stability of the SS Pt-RuO2 HNSs by reducing the energy barrier and increasing the dissociation energy of O* (Fig. 3e and f). In addition, different electron distributions will further affect the state density (DOS) of the surface-active atoms of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3g, the 4d orbitals of the active Ru atoms in Pt-RuO2 are closer to the Fermi level, which increases the OER activity. On the basis of experimental and computational analysis, a possible acidic OER mechanism is proposed (Fig. 3h). Water molecules are first adsorbed on the surface of SS Pt-RuO2 HNS, and the MOH* undergoes deprotonation to form MO* species. With the participation of water molecules, MO* further evolves into MOOH*, and eventually O2 forms and dissociates. Essentially, the intrinsic structural characteristics, particularly the electronic structure of the d-band center, determine the activation energy and reaction dynamics of the electrocatalyst, because it has a direct influence on the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates [79,80]. Tuning the electronic structure of RuO2 to obtain an appropriate adsorption energy is crucial for improving the OER performance [81–83]. Doping with foreign metals is considered an effective method for tuning the intrinsic electronic structure of RuO2. The VO generation energy is much higher than the redox energy of H2O/O2, which can thermodynamically prevent the peroxidation reaction of Ru-based catalysts. Foreign elements doping is a classical and effective strategy to widen the local band gap between the O 2p band center and Fermi energy level [62,84–86]. This will increase the energy barrier for lattice-oxygen oxidation and thus prevents the formation of VO. Using this strategy, Zhang et al. [81]. successfully modified the electronic structure of RuO2 by introducing W and Er, which improved the OER performance of RuO2 in 0.5 M H2SO4. The O 2p band center downshifted significantly, and the distance from the Fermi energy level increased when W and Er were added, making the generation of oxygen vacancies thermodynamically difficult and thus improving the stability and antioxidant capacity of Ru. As a result, the W and Er co-doped RuO2 exhibited high stability for more than 500 h in acid media at 10 mA cm−2. Heteroatom-doping is used as a practical means to improve the performance of RuO2 for acidic OER. However, the main disadvantage of conventional dopants is their static electron redistribution. Based on this, Qiao et al. [87]. reported a rhenium (Re) doped rutile RuO2 (Re0.06Ru0.94O2) electrocatalyst, which has good catalytic performance for acid OER. It was confirmed that the Re dopant obtains electrons from the Ru site in the OER phase to promote Ru site catalysis and contribute electrons back at large overpotentials to prevent Ru peroxidation and H2RuO5 formation via XAS (Fig. 4 a–f). It was further confirmed that Re doping reduced the adsorption energy of oxygen intermediates and enhanced the stability of Ru–O bonds in AEM (Fig. 4g and h), achieving a high mass activity of 500 A gcata − 1 and a stable number as high as S-number = 4.0 × 106 noxygen nRu − 1 via in situ characterization and DFT calculations. 2.1.2 Site collaboration to break the linear relationship The adsorption energy of OH*ads and OOH*ads and the adsorption energy of O have a scaling relation, which cannot be adjusted independently, resulting in an insurmountable scaling relationship in AEM. From this perspective, it can be inferred that if additional sites are introduced to break the scaling relationship between OOH* and OH*, it is possible to relieve the upper limit of the OER activity and thus decrease the OER overpotential to below 370 mV. Considerable efforts have been devoted toward the exploration of a strategy to independently modify OOH* and OH* adsorption. By far, the dual-site mechanism [88] and hydrogen-bond formation [89] have been regarded as the two most effective strategies to stabilize OOH*. Some studies have proposed that the dual-site mechanism is more favorable than a four proton-electron transfer mechanism on a single metal site. The single-site mechanism is sometimes analogous to the Lewis acid-base theory, in which the oxygen nucleophile attacks the electrophilic metal. In some cases, the dual-site mechanism be considered a radical mechanism involving the coupling of two adjacent oxygen atoms [88]. The major difference is that an O*O* bond is formed during the OER. As previously reported, this dual-site mechanism can significantly improve the OER performance by overcoming the scaling relationship if the OER occurs via the conventional AEM. The oxide of pyrochlores is a highly promising and efficient catalyst for the acidic oxygen evolution owing to its special octahedral shape that can modulate its electrochemical properties [90]. Sun et al. [91]. developed a series of Ir-doped yttrium ruthenate pyrochlore catalysts, wherein Ir is doped onto A2B2O7, resulting in enhanced interactions between RuO6 and IrO6 via shared oxygen and OAO bonding (Fig. 5 a). The catalyst required an overpotential of 220 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2, which is much lower than those required for RuO2 (300 mV) and IrO2 (350 mV). In addition, the catalyst showed no significant performance or structural degradation during the stability tests lasting over 2000 h. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) demonstrated that the reduced valence state of Ru and Ir in the pyrochlore contributed to its increased activity and stability. DFT calculations revealed that the potential RDS barrier to OOH* formation is greatly suppressed by the synergistic effect of the Ir and Ru sites, balancing the binding capacity of the d-band center and oxygen intermediates (Fig. 5b and e). Controlling the adsorption of OH* and OOH* at two different positions breaks the relevant scaling relationship. In contrast to the conventional mechanism, the RDS in this mechanism is the eventual deprotonation of OH* to yield O*, rather than the formation of OOH*. Compared to OH*, OOH* is more structurally sensitive due to the fact that there usually exists more intimate interactions between the pendent O in OOH* and the active sites [65]. Vojvodic et al. [89]. proposed a strategy to overcome the scaling relationship by using a three-dimensional nanoscale catalyst that provides a restricted reaction environment to allow selective interactions with specific intermediates. In this scheme, the nanoscale catalyst structure can interact selectively with OOH* intermediates (OH* adsorption is not affected). Using RuO2 and IrO2 (110) surfaces as models, they introduced a second surface to form channels and investigated the relationship between the adsorption capacities of OH* and OOH* and the width of the pores (Fig. 5f). Their results showed that the binding energy of OH* was constant when the channel width was larger than 6 Å. By contrast, the binding energy of OOH* was the lowest at 6 Å, indicating a stabilizing interaction between OOH* and the O atoms on the relative channel surface through the formation of specific hydrogen bonds. As a result, the channel overpotential of RuO2 at 7 Å is reduced to ∼0.2 eV, which is lower than the highest theoretical overpotential predicted by the scaling relationship (∼0.4 eV) (Fig. 5g). Recently, Wang et al. [92]. illustrated the proton and electron co-doping of RuO2 by simple physical co-mixing and magnetic stirring to construct RuOHO bonds within the RuO2 lattice. Hydrogen bonds modulated the electronic interactions between the Ru and O atoms and were spontaneously formed between neighboring O atoms. (Fig. 5h). The formation of hydrogen bonds was shown to not only improve RuO2 activity but also stabilize lattice oxygen and extend catalyst lifetime. The optimal sample functioned stably for over 50 h at 0.5 A cm−2 in a 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. 2.1.3 Introduction of a proton acceptor Although hydrogen-bond formation can enhance the stability of the OOH* intermediate, this improvement is limited. The OOH* intermediate can be stabilized by the introduction of a proton acceptor to produce OO* and H* (OO* + H*). The proton acceptor is a totally independent site, and the intermediate (OO* + H*) can be further stabilized [93]. As such, the activity of the catalyst is considerably increased. An alternative element with higher electronegativity can be introduced into the catalyst to activate oxygen on the surface, allowing it to function as a proton acceptor, or strong nucleophilic groups can be introduced on the catalyst surface. Zhang et al. [94]. controlled the embedding of Li ions in the RuO2 lattice to form a Li x RuO2 solid solution phase. Based on the working principle of lithium-ion batteries, the crystal structure of Li x RuO2 is identical to that of RuO2; however, it undergoes lattice expansion (Fig. 6 a–d). The eg occupancy is highly dependent on the binding strength of active Ru sites with oxo-intermediates, and optimum OER activity is usually obtained when eg occupancy approaches unity [95]. DFT showed that the occupancy of eg orbitals in Li0.5RuO2 catalysts was closer to uniformity than RuO2, and optimal OER activity could be achieved. At the same time, the center of the O 2p band is slightly closer to the Fermi level. Therefore, the enhancement of lithium intercalation activity is partly due to the modulation of Ru electronic structure (Fig. 6e). Synchrotron radiation X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and first-principles calculations showed that the electrons provided by Li embedded in the RuO2 crystals changed the electronic structure of Ru and O, reduced the valency of Ru, weakened the covalency of the RuO chemical bonds, and affected the local coordination of LiORu (Fig. 6f and g), thereby inhibiting the dissolution of Ru and improving the stability of the catalyst. The Bader charges of Ru and Li are positive, indicating that the lithium atoms are electron donors (Fig. 6h). The donated electrons of a lithium atom increase slightly when increasing lithium concentration, while the donated electrons of Ru decrease gradually, indicating the decrease of the valence state of Ru cations. The donation of electron from Li to O indicates the formation of LiO bond, which is expected to be strengthened with the increase of lithium concentration. Therefore, the strong interaction in this RuOLi local structure may further suppress the lattice oxygen involvement during OER, thus improving the stability of the Li x RuO2, when the apparent intercalated lithium concentration (x) reached 0.52, the overpotential of Li x RuO2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 was only 156 mV, which is much lower than that of the RuO2 matrix. Additionally, Lee et al. [96]. developed a method to utilize the oxophilicity of the first-cycle transition metal, Co, to pull Pt atoms toward the surface of RuO2, which facilitated the mixing of Pt in RuO2 to form PtCo–RuO2/C. The DFT and XAS results showed that the permeation of Pt into RuO2 and the formation of cationic vacancies induced by cobalt dissolution can reduce the d-band center of Ru and accelerate the adsorption and deprotonation of the OOH* intermediates, therefore guiding the mechanistic transformation from the LOM to AEM and further preventing Ru peroxidation and deactivation. Similarly, Sargent et al. [33]. considered integrating Ir and Sr into rutile RuO2 to enlarge the rutile lattice and increase the disorder in the crystal for both the active and stable phases (Fig. 7 a). Owing to the double modulation effect of Ir and Sr in the Sr–Ru–Ir ternary oxides, the valency and unoccupied e g orbital of Ru increased; therefore, the binding energy of the oxygen-containing intermediate in the AEM pathway is optimized. By calculating the screening by density functional theory (DFT), the ratio of the two regulators (Sr and Ir) was optimized, and Ru sites with high activity and high stability were obtained (Fig. 7b). At 10 mA cm−2, a low overpotential of 190 mV was obtained and maintained at 223 mV after 1500 h (Fig. 7c), with excellent stability due to interactions in the RuOIr local structure, which inhibited the LOM pathway during OER. This high activity is the result of optimization of oxygen intermediate binding energy on high-valent Ru sites formed after Sr and Ir doping. In addition to noble metals with higher electronegativity, the bridging oxygen on RuO2 can be activated by replacing Ru with inexpensive 3d transition metals (e.g., Ni, Co, and Mn) as proton acceptors [97–102]. Recently, Wang et al. [103]. reported a novel nickel-stabilized ruthenium dioxide (Ni-RuO2) electrocatalyst, which exhibited higher reactivity and stability in the acidic OER However, owing to the low oxygen evolution performance of RuO2 in acidic media and its susceptibility to oxidative decomposition over short-term continuous operation, the addition of Ni stabilized the crystal structure of RuO2 well, thus extending the lifetime of RuO2 by an order of magnitude. The Ni-RuO2 catalyst was used in PEM water electrolyzer, and its stability during water splitting was high during >1000 h operation at 200 mA cm−2. The AEM of the RuO2 catalysts was confirmed by DFT calculations and in situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS), which showed that the substitution of the Ni dopant at the ligand-saturated Ru-bridging site was more advantageous for improving the lattice stability of the surface Ru and subsurface oxygen, contributing to the improvement in OER durability (Fig. 7d and f). Furthermore, the Ni-RuO2 catalyst showed a significant improvement in activity, requiring a low overpotential of 214 mV and cell voltage of 2.10 V (no ohmic loss compensation or iR compensation) to realize an overall water-splitting current of 1.5 A cm−2 at room temperature. 2.2 Lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism The LOM involves an overflow of reactive oxygen from the lattice and its combination with an oxygen radical (O*), thereby participating in the OER cycle [104]. However, lattice oxygen is thermodynamically unfavorable for the reaction and requires the E f of the lattice to move to the 2p orbital of oxygen and lie above the redox energy of the O2/H2O pair. When the overlap between the 3d orbital of the metal and the 2p orbital of oxygen increases, the required bandgap energy for the reaction decreases, thereby favoring lattice oxygen transfer. In a typical DFT calculation of the LOM cycle, OH* deprotonates at the O site to produce OO*, followed by the removal of O2 molecules to produce VO [33]. Subsequently, another H2O* is adsorbed and deprotonated to form OH*. In this process, VO is replaced by OH*, and the adjacent surface lattice oxygen is protonated. The LOM does not include the concerted proton-electron transfer step of the conventional AEM [105]. Oxygen is generated through the direct coupling of O*O* bonds without involving the formation of OOH*, which can break the scaling relationship occurring in the AEM. Moreover, the surface of the catalyst can be destabilized by the migration and redox of lattice oxygen, leading to further remodeling or even the collapse of the structure [96]. Although the formed VO defects commonly induce the metal species to dissociate from the bulk or catalyst surface, resulting in rapid degradation and poor stability, the synergistic effect between VO defects and guest elements would efficiently regulate the OER activity in the Ru center. 2.2.1 Optimizing metal-oxygen covalency Based on the abovementioned basic principles, researchers have designed different strategies aimed at the development of the LOM that can improve the performance of RuO2 electrocatalysts, including atomic substitution at different metal sites, inclusion of atomic defects, and construction of ligand-oxygen defects, to effectively modulate metal-centered valency, metal-oxygen covalency, and orbital coupling. Metal-oxygen covalence reflects hybridization or overlap of metal d-O p orbitals, which can be quantified by O p band centers or charge transfer energies. Studies have shown that higher TM d-O p orbital hybridization in oxides can induce lattice oxygen oxidation, thereby forming Vo and improving OER activity [62,106]. However, cation leaching occurs when the adsorption rate of the catalyst subjected to surface intermediates, or the migration rate of bulk oxygen is not enough to compensate for the rate of VO formation on the surface [107]. The stronger the covalence of TM d-O p, the faster the M dissolution rate, resulting in surface changes and even structural collapse. In the following, we will discuss some recent work on regulating the effect of metal-oxygen covalence on OER activity in acidic media [108,109]. Yang et al. [110]. synthesized a pure-phase porous ruthenium ruthenate yttrium pyrochlore oxide (Y2[Ru1.6Y0.4]O7-δ) using an unconventional perchloric acid pore-forming agent; the compound showed good capability for acidic water oxidation. Because of the partial replacement of Y3+ on the B site, the induced oxygen lattice defects, together with the high specific surface area and the optimized band structure led to excellent activity (Fig. 8 a). The EXAFS data indicated a slight decrease in the local Ru–O bond distance in the Y2[Ru1.6Y0.4]O7 − δ porous pyrochlore in spite of the increase in the unit cell volume. Accordingly, the rational design of the B site and porous structure allowed Y2[Ru1.6Y0.4]O7 − δ to achieve a current density of 18.1 mA cm−2 at 1.50 V and to realize excellent acidic OER activity. Müller and coworkers, revealed that A-site substituent in yttrium ruthenium pyrochlores Y1.8M0.2Ru2O7−δ (M = Cu, Co, Ni, Fe, Y) tunes the O 2p band center and charge transfer energy [64]. The increased OER activity in acid and Vo density in Y1.8M0.2Ru2O7−δ is attributed to the weakened M−O bond strength with more covalent Ru–O bonds (adjacent to M−O) arising from the upshifted O 2p band closer to Fermi level (Fig. 8b and c). Overall, an increased oxygen lability and surface density of VO sites are hypothesized to favor the LOM pathway that is associated with decreased OER overpotentials. Whether in AEM or LOM mechanisms, the adsorption of hydroxyl groups at the active site of the catalyst is a critical step in the reaction. In addition, the adsorption of hydroxyl groups is determined as the rate-determining steps of LOM [111–114]. Metal substitution often helps to create hydroxyl groups on surfaces and fill oxygen vacancies. Based on this, Yang et al. [105] introduced metal Ru into the B site of Ruddlesden Sr2IrO4, causing it to produce a large number of hydroxyl groups on the surface and showing excellent activity and stability. The potential is 1.55 V at a current density of 8.06 mA cm−2, and the Tafel slope is 47 mV dec− 1 at an Ru/Ir ratio of 0.5/0.5. The catalyst can also maintain an overvoltage as low as 280 mV for >24 h at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. XPS revealed the presence of abundant hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface, probably formed by the substitution of metals with oxygen-rich species. Further studies on the electronic structure indicated that the RuORu bond angle becomes larger, resulting in a wider Ru 4d band and a larger overlap between Ir/Ru-4d and O 2p orbitals, which is favorable for fast OER kinetics. The introduction of Ru vacancy defects can regulate the energy converted from O* to OOH*, resulting in higher catalytic activity [115]. In addition, the asymmetric structure introduced by the oxygen vacancy can also modulate the acidic OER activity of the catalyst. Li et al. [116] successfully prepared Ru single-atom alloy catalysts using surface-defect engineering techniques to capture and stabilize single atoms. First, a Pt-based alloy with high oxidation resistance and solubility resistance were used as a carrier to create abundant defect sites on the alloy surface in order to stabilize and trap single-atom Ru via acid etching and electrochemical leaching. Furthermore, single-atom Ru dispersed on the metal support was regulated by the compression stress from the Pt-skin shell, in which Ru could be bonded with an oxygen-containing intermediate (Fig. 8d and e). Therefore, the monoatomic Ru alloy catalyst exhibited higher activity, peroxidation resistance, and solubility during the acidic OER with ∼30% lower overpotential and ∼10-fold higher stability than those of commercial Ru-based catalysts. Also, the catalyst exhibited 3.62% dissolution of Ru material after 28 h of chronopotentiometry (CP), in relation to 100% dissolution observed for commercial RuO2 catalysts. The DFT calculations showed that the compression strain of the Pt-skin shell modifies the electronic structure of atomically dispersed Ru, moving the d-band center of the Ru atom upward, optimizing the bonding strength of the oxygen intermediate and obtaining a volcanic curve relationship between the OER activity and alloy substrate (Fig. 8f). Charge-transfer analysis revealed that the improved peroxidation resistance of single-atom Ru is mainly attributed to the PtCu alloy, whose metallic coordination environment provides abundant electrons and prevents transition oxidation of the active component, Ru1 (Fig. 8g). 2.2.2 Carrier effect In electrocatalytic reactions, the conductivity can determine the electrocatalytic performance, which means that good electrical conductivity of catalyst can efficiently eliminate the barrier at the catalyst-electrolyte and catalyst-electrode interfaces in the electrocatalytic reaction, ensuring efficient energy conversion [117,118]. To accelerate the charge transfer of electrocatalytic materials, they are often loaded on different carriers, which not only allows the active components to be dispersed but also increases the strength of the catalyst, while the carriers themselves are generally not catalytically active [37]. It is noteworthy that the activity and stability of the catalyst also depend on the quality of the carrier loading. An excessively high loading or inappropriate amount of binder can cause catalyst shedding or collapse of the electrode structure owing to strong O2 bubble release. Therefore, designing self-supporting materials can enhance the interaction between the catalyst and carrier to improve the long-term stability of OER catalysts, which is preferable to simply mixing active materials with conductive carriers [119–125]. Carbon-based materials have good electrical conductivity [126–128] and are desirable nonprecious-metal oxygen-reduction catalysts. Although carbon is thermodynamically unstable under acidic conditions, its oxidation rate is determined by its surface characteristics. Deng et al. [129] controlled the oxidation of graphene encapsulated with Ru nanoparticles by adjusting the temperature and precisely controlling the reaction interface to construct a strong interfacial Ru center between RuO2 and graphene, resulting in RuNi2@G-250 catalysts that require only 227 mV to provide a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 0.5 M H2SO4 (Fig. 9 a). After the oxidation was optimized, the electron-rich graphene shell not only maintained its unique interface in the presence of severe acidic OER, but also acted as an electron reservoir to provide charge to the Ru active center, improving the resistance of RuO2 to peroxidation and corrosion, maintaining stability for more than 24 h, and showing significantly higher durability than commercial RuO2 (Fig. 9b and c). In addition to carbon materials, noble metal nanoparticles loaded on metal-oxide carriers is a very important and common class of catalyst systems. Although the noble metal particles constitute the main active phase, many studies suggest that the synergistic interaction between the metal and carrier is the key factor in the catalytic reaction. Wu et al. [130] prepared a layered metal-oxide nanofiber structure based on ferrite (La0.9Fe0.92Ru0.08O3 − δ, LFRO) using a modified electrospinning method. Oxide carriers with Ru and RuO2 nanoparticles anchored on LFRO substrates were formed based on an in-situ growth mechanism. Owing to the synergistic interaction between the metal and metal oxide as well as the large active surface area of the hollow fibers, the nanofibrous LFRO electrodes with RuO2 nanoparticles showed high OER activity and durability. Furthermore, the relationship between the catalytic activity and work function was investigated with the aid of atomic force microscopy. The results showed that the presence of a large number of oxygen vacancies caused an upward shift of the Fermi energy level, and the resulting low work function could accelerate the charge-transfer process, thus speeding up the kinetic process of the oxygen evolution reaction. Moreover, transition-metal carbides have excellent thermal resistance and corrosion resistance owing to its similar electron configuration to Pt, it can be used as a new type of catalyst, which can avoid the dependence on precious metals. The combination of the catalyst and the substrate can further optimize its electronic structure and improve the activity and stability of the catalyst. Xu et al. [131] used a theoretical design combined with an experimental strategy to construct a 0/2D composite structure of WC as a substrate combined with RuO2 nanoparticles (RuO2-WC NPs) embedded in ultrathin carbon nanosheets. The DFT calculations and experimental results showed that the prepared nanocomposite particles have a good lattice match between the WC substrate and RuO2, resulting in a catalyst-substrate interaction that is favorable to the catalytic reaction (Fig. 9d). This substrate effect can promote the migration of electrons in the WC substrate toward RuO2 and increase the electron concentration of Ru active sites. Accordingly, the electronic structure around the Ru active sites can be optimized, reducing the adsorption energies of the active sites and intermediate ligands in the OER process and correspondingly enhancing the stability and catalytic activity of the catalyst in the acidic OER (Fig. 9e and f). In addition, RuO2-WC NPs also have excellent acid HER performance, enabling the application of bifunctional electrocatalysts (OER/HER) in PEM, and the electrolyzer voltage is only 1.66 V at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. As stated above, the introduction of reliable and stable WC substrates can effectively reduce the loading of noble metals and improve the efficiency of noble metal utilization. 2.2.3 Experimental verification To demonstrate the involvement of lattice oxygen in oxygen evolution, several commonly used detection methods are described below. (1) The OER electrochemical activity is dependent on pH value. In the LOM regime, the charge-transfer energy of the catalyst drops significantly, accelerating the electron transfer and weakening the hydrogen affinity, allowing them to be separated in the pH-dependent PDS. Shao-Horn et al. [62] found that the OER activity of higher-valence oxides capable of executing the LOM was affected by pH, but the intrinsic OER activity of the catalyst in the AEM was independent of the solution pH. This is due to the presence of a non-coordinated proton-electron-transfer step in the LOM process, which is caused by a mismatch between the electron transfer kinetics and hydrogen affinity [132]. Therefore, it is noteworthy that the OER occurring via the LOM may exhibit pH-dependent activity, but this is not a key marker for LOM reactions. (2) Catalytic processes can be probed during reactions using in situ/operando spectroscopic techniques. In the LOM, lattice oxygen is formed through self-oxidation to form oxygen molecules; therefore, no OOH* intermediate species are produced, thus overcoming the linear relationship and enhancing the catalytic activity. This is an important piece of evidence for determining the LOM. In situ/operando IR spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, and XAS can provide accurate information about the dynamics occurring at the electrode surface and provide greater insights into the underlying reaction mechanisms [56,133,134]. Wu et al. [116] investigated the OER mechanism of the Ru1-Pt3Cu catalyst using in situ attenuated total reflection Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR). The detection of a characteristic vibrational absorption peak at ∼1212 cm−1 for surface-adsorbed OOH* suggests that for Ru1-Pt3Cu catalysts, the catalytic OER process mainly follows the AEM rather than the LOM. Lee et al. [57] used in situ synchrotron FTIR spectroscopy to directly observe O*O* bond formation represented by the peak at 1089 cm−1, elucidating the structural changes to the catalyst surface and further validating the catalyst mechanism. (3) Electrochemical differential mass spectrometry (DEMS). With the development of mass spectrometry and the improved design of electrochemical cells, DEMS has become a more commonly used tool for analysis and characterization. It is not only used for the qualitative and quantitative continuous detection of volatile products or intermediates during Faraday reactions but also to determine the amount of adsorbed mass (monolayer or sub-monolayer) on different electrode surfaces by means of desorption [135]. For the DEMS experiment, the catalyst is first labeled in terms of LSV cycle in the 18O-labeled electrolyte, and the oxygen signal of the 16O/18O-containing gaseous product is detected, as shown in Fig. 10 a. If lattice-oxygen activation of the catalyst occurs during OER labeling, the detector will capture a signal of 34O2 (18O16O), and for the AEM pathway, only 32O2 gas is detected. For example, ternary Ru–Ir–Ca oxides with significantly neutral OER activity have been shown to follow the LOM pathway using 18O-labeled DEMS, in which the 16O18O product was observed (Fig. 10b). To study the frequency of lattice-oxygen exchange, they also analyzed the 18O-labeled electrolytes using secondary-ion mass spectrometry. The depth distribution of the secondary-ion mass spectra of the 18O and 16O isotopes was 67% for RuIrCaOx (Fig. 10c), which further reinforces the argument that oxygen was inserted into the lattice matrix [136]. (4) Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy. Since the LOM mechanism requires the participation of lattice oxygen, a large number of oxygen vacancies are generated on the surface of the catalyst after lattice oxygen precipitation. It is one of the most direct and advanced methods for detecting oxygen vacancies. It provides information about the fingerprint of unpaired electrons on the surface, which signals the oxygen vacancies in the material. EPR spectroscopy is performed on ferromagnetic samples (with one unpaired electron). These samples can absorb electromagnetic radiation under the appropriate magnetic field, which means that this phenomenon may occur at specific frequencies depending on the following equation. h υ = g β B where h is Planck's constant, υ is the frequency, g is a constant, β is the Bohr magneton, and B is the applied magnetic field. The value of g depends on the nature of the radical, where materials with oxygen vacancies have a g value of ∼2.0 [137], which is the basis for determining the presence of oxygen vacancies in a material (Fig. 10d, e). 2.3 Oxide path mechanism As mentioned above, whether a catalyst is based on the AEM or LOM, it appears difficult to simultaneously achieve high activity and high stability, so there is an urgent need to establish a new mechanism for OER electrocatalysts with a clear structure-performance relationship [57]. Remarkably, the recently discovered OPM opens a new avenue to develop excellent OER electrocatalysts (Fig. 2c). Owing to the symmetry and special bimetallic sites with appropriate atomic spacings for the elaborately designed electrocatalysts, the OPM is more suitable than the AEM or LOM. This allows direct O* radical coupling without defects in the oxygen vacancies as well as the coupling of other reactive intermediates (e.g., OOH*). Specifically, OH* is formed at two adjacent sites on the catalyst surface by successive deprotonation to form two O* radicals, and then direct coupling of O*O* yields oxygen molecules. Ideally, OPM-based multiphase electrocatalysts can overcome the structural relationship without sacrificing stability and are expected to be advantageous for promoting the coupling of O*O* radicals with low energy barriers. Lee et al. [57] reported an α-MnO2 nanofiber material supported Ru single-atom array electrocatalyst (12 Ru/MnO2) that satisfied the OPM pathway. The ion-exchange reaction between Ru ions and α-MnO2 resulted in the formation of small, regularly arranged chains of Ru atoms by replacing the Mn atom sites in the crystalline α-MnO2 carrier with metallic Ru atoms (Fig. 11 a and b). The array of Ru atoms in 12 Ru/MnO2 was shown to consist of symmetrical Ru sites. Moreover, the Ru–Ru distance in this structure was found to decrease significantly (to 2.9 Å) based on the results of the EXAFS analysis and theoretical calculations, which is shorter than that of commercial ruthenium dioxide (3.1 Å). Therefore, this allows direct coupling of the adsorbed reactive oxygen on the two neighboring Ru atoms during the electrolysis of water to rapidly generate oxygen (Fig. 11c and d). In addition, the dynamic replacement reaction between the manganese oxide carrier and ruthenium overcomes the problem of ruthenium leaching. This allows the catalyst to acquire a unique self-healing capability, substantially reducing the reaction energy barrier and thus avoiding catalyst corrosion caused by the involvement of lattice oxygen in the aqueous decomposition reaction. During the OER, the Ru atoms on the defect side of the fresh 12 Ru/MnO2 were first dissolved in the acidic electrolyte, and then the Ru ions were recaptured at the expense of partial leaching of Mn to more energetically stable sites (such as ordered sites). At 10 mA cm−2, the overpotential of 12 Ru/MnO2 is 161 mV, and it has excellent long-term durability (200 h), making it one of the highest-performance OER catalysts (Fig. 11e). Furthermore, the results of the calculation of the energy distribution of AEM indicate that AEM has a potential barrier of 0.48 eV compared with the OPM, which indicates that the OPM is more advantageous for 12 Ru/MnO2 than for the AEM in OER (Fig. 11f and g). Recently, inspired by the structural advantages of dimensionally stable anodes, Lu et al. [138] successfully synthesized Zn-doped RuO2 (py-RuO2:Zn) nanowire arrays with excellent acidic OER performance on Ti substrate by simple pyrolysis. The substitution doping of Zn not only adjusted the morphology of the catalyst, but also produced a large number of VO defects and low-valence Ru sites. Self-supporting py-RuO2:Zn nanowires exhibit impressive OER activity and durability at 0.5 M H2SO4, low overpotentials of 173, 304, and 373 mV at 10, 500, and 1000 mA cm−2, respectively, and very modest degradations during the continuous test at 10 mA cm−2 for 1000 h and 50 mA cm−2 for 100 h. Experimental and theoretical studies show that VO defects and Zn dopants led to weakened binding of active Ru central oxygen adsorbent, and more interestingly, moderate adsorption of OH* species at Zn site. Therefore, the Ru−Zn dual-site OPM is advantageous and reduces the reaction energy barrier and avoids excessive oxidation of OER metal sites, thereby protecting the active centers and significantly enhancing OER activity. Among them, the presence of Zn dopants and VO defects stabilizes the structure of RuO2 matrix, and the excellent stability is better than that of commercial RuO2 and recently reported RuO2-based catalysts 3 Conclusions and perspectives The acidic OER is important for improving the efficiency of PEM water electrolysis, and the preparation of electrode materials with excellent acidic oxygen evolution characteristics is very important. In this paper, the OER catalytic mechanism, catalyst optimization strategy, experimental verification and Ru-based electrocatalysts with excellent activity and stability under acidic conditions are reviewed, and the structure-performance relationship of catalysts is studied. The methods for optimizing the activity and stability of catalysts, as well as the comparison of kinetic properties, are summarized in detail in Table 1 . Although many suggestions for improvement have been made, the performance of most catalysts is not satisfactory, especially in terms of stability. Therefore, several issues described below remain to be further investigated to realize the large-scale application of Ru-based electrocatalytic materials. In addition, the future development of the acidic OER is prospected accordingly. 3.1 In situ characterization First, many studies in recent years have revealed that the structure of the catalyst changes drastically during the kinetic OER. Determining the structural evolution or the interactions between active sites and adsorbents is significant in understanding the underlying mechanisms. Although ex situ characterization can provide a range of structural information, such techniques are inherently ineffective because the sample will inevitably be exposed to air before entering a high-vacuum environment, thus changing the structure of the catalyst. Furthermore, only considering the pre/post-reaction state of the sample does not provide insights into the dynamic mechanisms involved in the activation of the catalyst. For example, in the OER, the active site may undergo reversible structural changes; thus, an in-depth study of the transient state at the applied potential is necessary. Currently, most of the in-situ characterization techniques, such as scanning tunneling electron microscopy (STEM), TEM, FTIR spectroscopy, and synchrotron radiation, allow detailed analyses of the evolution of the active sites and intermediate species. Using these methods, the kinetics of the samples can be determined under OER conditions, providing important information for stabilizing the catalytic structure. 3.2 Dissolution-redeposition of Ru metal Second, the dissolution-redeposition of Ru ions in aqueous solution is a key factor to consider in the actual OER process. This provides a new understanding of the reconstruction of the catalytically active center. In addition, the optimization of the deposition mechanism and the influencing factors of metal ions on different substrates, i.e., deposition rate and direction, are key issues to be addressed. 3.3 Combining theory and experiment Third, owing to the complex structural changes during the OER, the original active site in the OER electrocatalyst is different from the active component after the reaction, which makes it difficult to determine the structure-activity relationship. Furthermore, although a trade-off between activity and stability always exists for the AEM and LOM, it still remains controversial whether the factors influencing activity and stability are directly related. A qualitative evaluation is of crucial significance to reveal the activity and stability origins of the OER electrocatalysts. In situ characterization combined with DFT simulations could allow further understanding of the mechanism. An acknowledged drawback, however, is that the dynamic changes of the bonding type and electron transfer following potential variation in pre-catalysis, on-site, and large potential regions cannot be simulated via DFT. Furthermore, once a reliable relationship has been established, artificial intelligence machine learning, regarded as a cutting-edge technology in materials science and catalysis, will allow for high-throughput screening of commercially available OER electrocatalysts for PEMWEs. As a result, PEMWE technology will enter a new stage of development and implementation. Finally, with a full understanding of the OER mechanism under acidic conditions, a more in-depth study of its reaction conditions is needed for expanding the practical application scope toward bridging the gap between experimental and scaled-up applications. In particular, factors such as acidity and surface blistering, which are typically overlooked in laboratory tests, have a more significant impact on membrane electrode performance during operation. Therefore, OER electrocatalysts must be designed under these conditions to achieve long-term stability. coredata.dc:description: Water electrolysis using proton-exchange membranes is one of the most promising technologies for carbon-neutral and sustainable energy production. Generally, the overall efficiency of water splitting is limited by the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Nevertheless, a trade-off between activity and stability exists for most electrocatalytic materials in strong acids and oxidizing media, and the development of efficient and stable catalytic materials has been an important focus of research. In this view, gaining in-depth insights into the OER system, particularly the interactions between reaction intermediates and active sites, is significantly important. To this end, this review introduces the fundamentals of the OER over Ru-based materials, including the conventional adsorbate evolution mechanism, lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism, and oxide path mechanism. Moreover, the up-to-date progress of representative modifications for improving OER performance is further discussed with reference to specific mechanisms, such as tuning of geometric, electronic structures, incorporation of proton acceptors, and optimization of metal-oxygen covalency. Finally, some valuable insights into the challenges and opportunities for OER electrocatalysts are provided with the aim to promote the development of next-generation catalysts with high activity and excellent stability.

coredata.dc:title: Progress on the mechanisms of Ru-based electrocatalysts for the oxygen evolution reaction in acidic media
